papers.title: A whole-planet model of the Earth without life for terrestrial exoplanet studies
papers.abstract: As the only known habitable (and inhabited) planet in the universe, Earth informs our search for life elsewhere. Future telescopes like the Habitable Worlds Observatory (HWO) will soon look for life on rocky worlds around Sun-like stars, so it is critical that we understand how to distinguish habitable planets from inhabited planets. However, it remains unknown if life is necessary to maintain a habitable planet, or how all of the components of an evolving planet impact habitability over time. To address these open questions, we present a coupled interior-atmosphere evolution model of the Earth without life from 50 Myr to 5 Gyr that reproduces 19 key observations of the pre-industrial Earth within measurement uncertainties after 4.5 Gyr. We also produce a reflected light spectrum covering the possible wavelength range of HWO. Our findings support the view that life is not required to maintain habitable surface conditions. The model presented here is apt for predicting the long-term habitability of Earth-like exoplanets via evolving bulk properties. By generating realistic reflected light spectra from evolved atmospheric states, this model represents significant progress towards whole-planet modeling, which may ultimately provide a robust abiotic baseline for interpreting biosignature observations with HWO.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine you're a detective trying to identify signs of life on distant planets, but you've never seen what a lifeless habitable world looks like. That's the challenge facing astronomers today. With powerful new telescopes coming online that can actually study the atmospheres of Earth-like planets orbiting other stars, scientists need to know: what would Earth look like if life had never evolved here? This isn't just academic curiosity‚Äîit's essential for distinguishing between planets that could support life and planets that actually do support life. Understanding this difference could help us find our first confirmed alien biosphere.

**What They Did**

Researchers created an incredibly detailed computer simulation of Earth's entire history‚Äîbut with a twist. They erased all life from the equation and ran the clock forward for 5 billion years to see what would happen. Their virtual Earth included everything from volcanic activity and atmospheric chemistry to how the interior and surface interact over geological time. Think of it like running a massive, planet-scale experiment that follows every major process that shapes a world, from the churning of molten rock deep underground to how gases cycle through the atmosphere. They then compared their lifeless Earth to 19 key measurements of our actual pre-industrial planet to see how realistic their model was.

**Key Findings**

The simulation revealed something remarkable: Earth would still be habitable today even without life. Their virtual lifeless planet matched real Earth's characteristics with stunning accuracy after 4.5 billion years of evolution. The model also generated what this lifeless Earth would look like to future space telescopes‚Äîessentially creating a cosmic "control sample" that shows what a habitable but uninhabited world's light signature should be.

**Looking Forward**

This research provides astronomers with their first reliable baseline for spotting life on distant worlds. When the next generation of space telescopes begins studying potentially habitable exoplanets, scientists will finally know what to expect from a lifeless world‚Äîmaking any deviations that much more exciting as potential signs of alien life.

papers.title: Dynamical Interactions and Habitability in the TOI-700 Multi-Planet System
papers.abstract: The discovery of a second earth sized planet (TOI-700e) interior to the habitable candidate TOI-700d has prompted further research into this system, as the additional planet makes the TOI-700 system a tightly packed multi-planet system with multiple planets in the habitable zone, like TRAPPIST-1. In this work, we use the planetary evolution code VPLanet to assess the potential habitability of TOI-700d and TOI-700e. We first examine their orbital dynamics to evaluate the influence of planet-planet interactions on the planet spin, obliquity, and eccentricity. We then investigate whether these interactions are sufficient to cause either TOI-700d or e to be perturbed out of a habitable state, and whether we expect either planet could retain surface oceans over Gyr timescales. Together, these analyses allow us to assess the long-term habitability prospects of both TOI-700d and TOI-700e. We find that multi-planet interactions in the TOI-700 system do not prevent either planet from potentially retaining habitable conditions; however, we find that TOI-700e is located very near the boundary of the tidally locked habitable zone (arXiv:1705.10362), suggesting further work is needed to determine whether it is truly habitable.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine finding not just one, but two potentially habitable worlds orbiting the same star‚Äîplanets where liquid water could exist on the surface, making them possible havens for life as we know it. That's exactly what astronomers have discovered in the TOI-700 system, located about 100 light-years from Earth. This system now joins the ranks of TRAPPIST-1 as one of the rare multi-planet systems where several worlds might be capable of supporting life. Understanding whether these planets can actually maintain habitable conditions over billions of years is crucial for our search for life beyond Earth and helps us understand how common potentially livable worlds might be in our galaxy.

**What They Did**

The researchers used a sophisticated computer program called VPLanet to run cosmic simulations of the TOI-700 system over billions of years. Think of it like running a celestial video game in fast-forward‚Äîthey watched how the planets' orbits evolve, how they spin, how tilted they are (like Earth's 23-degree tilt that gives us seasons), and whether their paths around the star remain stable or become chaotic. They also examined whether the gravitational tug-of-war between the planets would knock either world out of the "Goldilocks zone"‚Äîthat sweet spot where temperatures are just right for liquid water to exist on a planet's surface.

**Key Findings**

The good news is that both planets appear capable of staying habitable for billions of years, despite their gravitational interactions. The planetary dance doesn't seem violent enough to destroy their chances for life. However, TOI-700e faces a significant challenge: it sits right at the edge of what scientists call the "tidally locked habitable zone." This means the planet might always show the same face to its star, like the Moon does to Earth, creating one permanently hot side and one permanently frozen side.

**Looking Forward**

This research brings us closer to answering one of humanity's most profound questions: Are we alone? The TOI-700 system provides an excellent laboratory for testing our understanding of planetary habitability, and future space telescopes may be able to analyze these worlds' atmospheres for signs of water vapor or even biosignatures‚Äîchemical fingerprints of life itself.

papers.title: What to make of the Earth's curiously intermediate land fraction?
papers.abstract: Approximately two-thirds of the Earth, the only known inhabited planet, is covered in ocean. Why not 0.01% or 99.99%? It has been previously suggested that this may represent a certain degree of fine-tuning, and thus perhaps observers are a-priori more likely to develop on those rare worlds with nearly equal land-ocean ratios, such as our own. In this work, we take the single datum of the Earth and then use Bayesian inference to compare four models for the probability distribution of a planet becoming inhabited by observers as a function of land-fraction, f, which we classify as i) land-centric ii) ocean-centric iii) equi-centric and iv) indifference. We find that no model is strongly favoured over the others, but that 1) the land-centric model is disfavoured over all others, and, 2) the equi-centric model is favoured over all competitors. Further, we show that more extreme models with heavy tail-weighting are strongly disfavoured even when conditioned upon the Earth alone. For example, a land-centric model where the median planet has f=0.82 (or greater) is in strong tension with our existence. Finally, we consider the potential addition of more data via Mars or exoplanets. Should paleo-Mars have once harboured life and had f<0.20, then this would strongly favour the ocean-centric model for life, over a land-centric hypothesis. We show that strong evidence for/against the equi-centric model versus its competitors would likely require at least a dozen inhabited exoplanets, offering a well-motivated sample size for future experiments.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Earth's surface is roughly two-thirds ocean and one-third land‚Äîbut is this balance just cosmic coincidence, or could it be a key ingredient for life as we know it? As we discover thousands of planets beyond our solar system, this question becomes crucial for understanding where else life might exist. If Earth's land-to-ocean ratio represents some kind of "Goldilocks zone"‚Äînot too much land, not too little, but just right‚Äîthen truly habitable worlds might be much rarer than we think. This research tackles one of astrobiology's most fundamental puzzles: what makes a planet suitable for complex life?

**What They Did**

The researchers treated Earth as a cosmic laboratory, using our planet's 67% ocean coverage as their starting point. They created four different mathematical models, each representing a theory about what land-ocean balance works best for life. Think of it like testing four different recipes: one favoring mostly land planets, another favoring mostly ocean worlds, a third preferring balanced planets like Earth, and a fourth suggesting the ratio doesn't matter at all. Using a statistical method called Bayesian inference‚Äîessentially a sophisticated way of updating beliefs based on evidence‚Äîthey tested which models best explain why life emerged on a planet with Earth's specific characteristics.

**Key Findings**

The results were surprisingly nuanced. No single model emerged as a clear winner, but some important patterns appeared. Planets dominated by land (like a world that's 82% continents) seem unlikely to support life like ours. Meanwhile, the "balanced planet" model‚Äîfavoring worlds with roughly equal land and ocean‚Äîperformed slightly better than its competitors. Most intriguingly, the researchers found that having some ancient life on Mars, if it existed on a more ocean-dominated early Mars, would strongly support the idea that watery worlds are better for life.

**Looking Forward**

This work provides a roadmap for future exoplanet research. The scientists calculate that we'd need to find about a dozen life-bearing worlds to really test these theories‚Äîa challenging but potentially achievable goal as our planet-hunting technology improves. Understanding the ideal land-ocean balance could help prioritize which of the thousands of known exoplanets deserve our closest attention in the search for life.

papers.title: Ocean Circulation on Tide-locked Lava Worlds: 3D Modeling with a Simple Boundary Iteration Method
papers.abstract: Tide-locked lava worlds are surface-melted rocky planets under 1:1 tidally locked orbit (i.e., synchronously rotating) with orbital period being equal to rotation period and with permanent hot dayside and cold nightside. Previous studies on this type of planets employed scaling analyses and two-dimensional (2D) simulations. This work is a continuation of the previous researches but including the effect of the Coriolis force and the simulation domain is extended to a 3D global sphere. We find that under the condition with thermal-only forcing (without surface wind stresses), the area-mean ocean depth is about 50--300 m (depending on vertical diffusivity) and the area-mean effect of horizontal ocean heat transport (in the order of 10^3 to 10^4 W m^-2) is significantly smaller than stellar radiation (in the order of 10^6 W m^-2 at the substellar region), being consistent with previous results. Different from 2D results, due to the effect of the Coriolis force, large-scale horizontal gyres form on the dayside, ocean currents near the west boundaries are much stronger than that near the east boundaries (called as ``western intensification''), the deepest ocean is not right at the substellar point but in the middle latitudes as the vertical diffusivity is moderate or large, and meanwhile there exists significant asymmetry between the west and the east of the substellar point. These results establish a first picture for the 3D thermal-driven ocean circulation and confirm that the lava ocean should be shallow on tide-locked lava worlds.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine a world so close to its star that one side permanently bakes in eternal daylight while the other freezes in endless night. These "tide-locked lava worlds" aren't science fiction‚Äîthey're real planets we've discovered orbiting other stars. The dayside gets so hot that rock itself melts into vast oceans of liquid lava. Understanding how these alien seas behave helps us grasp the incredible diversity of worlds beyond our solar system and pushes the boundaries of what we know about planetary physics. These extreme environments also serve as natural laboratories for studying how heat moves around planets, knowledge that deepens our understanding of atmospheric and oceanic processes everywhere.

**What They Did**

The researchers created the first comprehensive 3D computer simulation of lava oceans on these exotic worlds. Think of it like building a detailed weather model, but instead of predicting rain, they're tracking currents of molten rock flowing across an entire planet. Previous studies had only looked at simplified 2D slices, like examining a single cross-section of Earth's oceans. This new approach captures the full complexity of a spherical world, including the effects of planetary rotation‚Äîthe same force that creates swirling hurricanes on Earth. They fed their model the physics of how liquid rock flows, cools, and responds to the extreme temperature differences between the scorching day side and frigid night side.

**Key Findings**

The lava oceans are surprisingly shallow‚Äîonly 50 to 300 meters deep on average, about the height of a skyscraper. Despite the dramatic temperature contrasts, these molten seas don't transport much heat from day to night side compared to the star's intense radiation. The most fascinating discovery involves massive swirling currents called gyres that form on the day side, similar to ocean currents on Earth but made of liquid rock. Due to planetary rotation, the western edges of these lava seas have much stronger currents than the eastern edges, and the deepest parts aren't directly under the star but offset toward the middle latitudes.

**Looking Forward**

This research provides our first realistic picture of what these alien worlds actually look like, moving beyond simplified models to capture their true complexity. As we discover more exoplanets with advanced telescopes, these simulations will help us interpret observations and identify the signatures of lava worlds in telescope data, bringing us closer to understanding the full menagerie of planets in our galaxy.

papers.title: Helium escape in context: Comparative signatures of four close-in exoplanets
papers.abstract: Observations of escaping atmospheres on close-in exoplanets show a wide range in the strength and morphology of He I 10830 A and H I absorption. Scaling relations attempt to link the He I signal to XUV irradiation, mass loss, and bulk planetary parameters. We test these relations with a comparative analysis of HD209458b, HD189733b, HD149026b, and GJ1214b using a 1D hydrodynamic, multi-species, full-atmosphere escape model. For the benchmark HD209458b, our previously validated solution reproduces the observed He I and Ha transit depths without imposing composition constraints. HD189733b exhibits comparable He I depths, but the broadest reported profiles require ~12 km/s of additional non-thermal broadening, whereas more recent measurements are narrower, consistent with our predictions. For HD149026b, despite similar system properties, our model shows that higher gravity suppresses escape and enhances diffusive separation, depleting helium at high altitudes and yielding extremely weak He I absorption. For the sub-Neptune GJ1214b, H/He-only models overestimate He I absorption; including H2 and its ions (H2+, H3+, HeH+) lowers the escape rate and modifies the ion/electron balance, reducing the metastable helium densities. Compared against scaling relations, HD189733b observations and our HD149026b prediction fall below the trend, whereas some observations of HD209458b and GJ1214b are consistent; however, the observed transit depths are variable. Across all targets, we find diffusive separation of helium and hydrogen, which may explain why sub-solar He/H ratios are often required in simplified models. We conclude that interpreting He I and Ha absorption requires first-principles models that include self-consistent temperature and velocity profiles, multi-species transport, and molecular chemistry.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

When planets orbit extremely close to their stars, the intense radiation can literally blow their atmospheres into space‚Äîlike a cosmic hair dryer stripping away the air we breathe. Scientists can detect this atmospheric escape by watching for specific wavelengths of light absorbed by helium and hydrogen as these gases stream away from distant worlds. Understanding which planets lose their atmospheres and why helps us predict what types of worlds can sustain thick atmospheres over billions of years, potentially affecting their ability to support life as we know it.

**What They Did**

The researchers studied four well-known exoplanets that orbit very close to their host stars, analyzing how helium escapes from each world's atmosphere. Instead of relying on simplified mathematical shortcuts that other scientists often use, they built detailed computer models that track how gases behave as they heat up and escape into space. Think of it like creating a sophisticated weather forecast, but for planetary atmospheres being blasted by starlight. They then compared their predictions to actual telescope observations of these planets to see how well their models matched reality.

**Key Findings**

The team discovered that each planet loses its atmosphere differently, even when they seem similar at first glance. One planet, HD149026b, has stronger gravity that suppresses atmospheric escape and causes helium to separate from hydrogen‚Äîlike oil and water separating in a bottle. For the smaller planet GJ1214b, including molecular hydrogen in their calculations dramatically changed the results, showing that previous simpler models overestimated helium loss. Surprisingly, the signals varied significantly between different telescope observations of the same planets, suggesting these atmospheric processes may change over time.

**Looking Forward**

This research reveals that there's no universal formula for predicting atmospheric escape‚Äîeach planet is unique. Scientists will need more sophisticated models and additional observations to truly understand how close-in planets evolve. This knowledge will prove crucial as we discover smaller, potentially habitable worlds and try to determine which ones might retain the stable atmospheres necessary for life.

papers.title: Chasing the Tides: Searching for Orbital Decay Signatures in Transit Timing Data and Tidal Models for 20 Hot Jupiters
papers.abstract: In this work, we present a transit timing variation analysis for 20 hot Jupiter systems, which we interpret with theoretical tidal dissipation models. For the majority of the sample, we conclude that a constant orbital period model represents the timing data best. Only WASP-12 b, TrES-1 b and WASP-121 b exhibit a changing orbital period, according to the most up-to-date results. We updated the orbital decay rate of WASP-12 b to P = -29.4 ¬± 4.0 ~ms~yr^-1 and the corresponding stellar tidal quality factor to Q_*^ = 1.72 ¬± 0.18 √ó 10^5. For TrES-1 b, the median quadratic model suggests a period decrease at a rate of -14.9 ¬± 0.6 ~ms~yr^-1, but the corresponding Q_*^ = 570 ¬± 60 does not agree with the theoretical estimates, which suggest Q_*^ ~ 10^6 due to internal gravity wave dissipation. Lastly, WASP-121 b exhibits orbital growth at a rate of 15.1 ¬± 0.8 ~ms~yr^-1, and theoretical results support outward migration due to strong inertial wave dissipation.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine planets locked in a cosmic dance with their stars, sometimes spiraling inward toward fiery destruction, other times drifting outward to safety. This research helps us understand one of the most dramatic processes in planetary systems: when massive planets called "hot Jupiters" gradually change their orbits around their host stars. These gas giants, similar to Jupiter but orbiting much closer to their stars, experience incredible gravitational forces that can literally reshape their futures. By studying how these planets move, we gain crucial insights into how planetary systems evolve and what might happen to worlds beyond our solar system over millions of years.

**What They Did**

The researchers acted like cosmic detectives, carefully timing when 20 different hot Jupiter planets passed in front of their stars‚Äîevents called transits. Just as you might notice a train arriving slightly early or late each day, these scientists measured tiny changes in when each planet completed its orbit. They collected years of timing data and used mathematical models to determine whether each planet's orbital period was staying constant, shrinking (meaning the planet is spiraling inward), or growing (meaning it's moving outward). They then compared their observations with theoretical models that predict how gravitational forces and tidal effects should influence these planetary orbits.

**Key Findings**

Most of the planets showed rock-steady orbits with no detectable changes. However, three planets revealed dramatic orbital evolution. WASP-12 b is spiraling toward its star, with its orbital period shrinking by about 29 milliseconds each year‚Äîa death spiral that will eventually lead to the planet's destruction. TrES-1 b is also moving inward, losing 15 milliseconds annually. Just as you might notice a train arriving slightly early or late each day, these scientists measured tiny changes in when each planet completed its orbit. They then compared their observations with theoretical models that predict how gravitational forces and tidal effects should influence these planetary orbits.

papers.title: Modeling the Dynamics and Thermochemistry for the Outer Atmospheres of the Ultra-hot Jupiter WASP-121b
papers.abstract: We present three-dimensional simulations of the ultra-hot Jupiter (UHJ) WASP-121b from the planetary surface to extended outflows, coupling hydrodynamics with consistent non-equilibrium thermochemistry, ray-tracing radiative transfer, and hydrodynamics using the GPU-accelerated Kratos framework. The fiducial model exhibits several atmospheric layers, including the lower atmospheres controlled by day-night circulation, and transonic photoevaporative outflows at higher altitudes shaped into two spiral arms by the stellar gravity and orbital motion effects. Different species could trace different regions: Fe probes rotation-dominated inner layers, Na maps dense spiral arms where recombination balances photoionization, and HŒ± and He 10830~ A features trace progressively more extended, ionized gas. With spiral arm velocities reaching ~ 40~ km\ s^-1 projected along the line of sight, this morphology explains observed high-velocity Na and HŒ± absorption features without requiring significant super-rotation jet streams. Parametric studies reveal complex dependencies on stellar irradiation: enhanced FUV intensifies outflows and extends spiral arms spatially and kinematically, while EUV and X-ray expands spiral structures into attenuated, ionized regions. Stellar wind confinement compresses the dayside outflow and enhances metastable helium absorption. This work demonstrates that current and future transmission spectral observations that probe multiple species can provide important constraints on astrophysical environments of UHJs by comparing state-of-the-art simulations.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine a planet so close to its star that its atmosphere is literally boiling away into space, creating cosmic weather patterns unlike anything in our solar system. WASP-121b is one of these "ultra-hot Jupiters"‚Äîa gas giant orbiting so near its star that temperatures soar above 4,000¬∞F. Understanding how these extreme worlds lose their atmospheres helps us grasp the incredible diversity of planets beyond our solar system and reveals the violent processes that shape planetary evolution across the universe.

**What They Did**

Scientists created the most detailed computer simulation ever made of WASP-121b's escaping atmosphere. Think of it like creating a virtual planet and watching how different gases behave as they get blasted by intense starlight. Their digital model tracked everything from dense lower atmosphere layers (like Earth's weather patterns) all the way out to where gas streams off into space. They followed individual chemical elements‚Äîiron, sodium, hydrogen, and helium‚Äîto see where each one travels as the planet's atmosphere gets stripped away by stellar radiation.

**Key Findings**

The simulation revealed that WASP-121b's escaping atmosphere forms two giant spiral arms, like a cosmic pinwheel, stretching far into space. These spirals spin at incredible speeds‚Äîabout 25 miles per second‚Äîfast enough to circle Earth's equator in under an hour. Different elements paint different parts of this atmospheric portrait: iron stays closer to the planet in rotating layers, sodium traces the dense spiral arms, while hydrogen and helium mark the more distant, ionized regions. This spiral structure elegantly explains mysterious high-speed signals astronomers have detected in the planet's atmosphere without needing exotic wind patterns.

**Looking Forward**

This breakthrough shows how cutting-edge simulations can decode the complex signals we receive from distant worlds. As new space telescopes come online, astronomers will be able to compare these detailed predictions with real observations, turning exoplanets from distant points of light into fully realized worlds with their own unique atmospheric personalities and evolutionary stories.

papers.title: Detecting and Characterizing Companions with a Calibrated Gaia DR2, DR3, and Hipparcos Catalog (G23H)
papers.abstract: Gaia DR4 epoch astrometry will enable the detection of thousands of exoplanets through astrometric motion. Here, we present a composite catalog and modeling framework that extracts the maximum information from existing Hipparcos and Gaia data releases. We calibrate Gaia DR2 proper motions and DR3-DR2 scaled position differences against the Gaia DR3 reference frame, and combine these with the Hipparcos-Gaia Catalog of Accelerations, the Hipparcos intermediate astrometric data, Gaia astrometric excess noise, and Gaia radial velocity variability constraints. We implement a joint likelihood model for these data in Octofitter that marginalizes over Gaia's unpublished observation epochs. This results in full orbit posteriors that can be computed uniformly for a large class of companions. We compare these posteriors to published orbital solutions for 25 stellar binaries from the Sixth Catalog of Orbits of Visual Binary Stars, recovering all companions at high significance and broadly consistent orbital separations. We then recover independent evidence to support 94 of 120 tested Jovian exoplanetary systems from the NASA Exoplanet Archive (plus 3 known stellar companions, and one previously detected planet we now rule out). We demonstrate that in cases like 14 Her b, the posteriors confirm the planetary nature of a signal using only Gaia and Hipparcos data. We find no false positives among 25 RV-quiet standard stars without significant Hipparcos-Gaia accelerations. Our method can break degeneracies inherent to proper motion anomaly or excess noise modeling alone by resolving orbital curvature within the Gaia baseline. The catalog and updated Octofitter are made publicly available to the community.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to spot a tiny firefly buzzing around a blazing campfire from miles away‚Äîthat's essentially the challenge astronomers face when hunting for planets orbiting other stars. Most exoplanets are discovered indirectly, by detecting how they make their host stars wobble or dim slightly. This new research represents a major leap forward in our planet-hunting abilities, using incredibly precise measurements of stellar motion to confirm the existence of dozens of distant worlds. As we stand on the brink of discovering potentially habitable planets, these techniques could help us find Earth-like worlds that might harbor life.

**What They Did**

The researchers combined data from two space-based observatories‚ÄîHipparcos and Gaia‚Äîthat measure star positions with extraordinary precision. Think of it like having two extremely steady hands holding rulers to track how stars move across the sky over decades. When a planet orbits a star, it causes the star to wobble in a predictable pattern, much like how a figure skater's body moves when spinning with arms extended. By carefully calibrating and combining measurements spanning nearly 30 years, the team created a powerful new tool to detect these tiny wobbles. They then used advanced computer modeling to analyze the motion patterns and determine whether unseen companions were planets or other stars.

**Key Findings**

The method successfully confirmed 94 out of 120 known Jupiter-sized planets they tested, providing independent verification using only stellar motion data. Remarkably, they recovered evidence for all 25 stellar binary systems in their comparison sample. In some cases, like the planet orbiting the star 14 Hercules, their analysis confirmed the planet's existence using completely different data than the original discovery. Importantly, they found no false alarms when testing 25 stars known to have no companions.

**Looking Forward**

This work sets the stage for Gaia's upcoming data release, which could reveal thousands of new exoplanets through stellar wobbles alone. The publicly available tools and methods will help astronomers worldwide hunt for planets, potentially including Earth-sized worlds in the habitable zones around nearby stars.
